actual:
by greg b. smith daily news staff writer

a mob-controlled owner of the popular ranch 1 fast-food chain cooked up a unique recipe for laundering cash - he used a brooklyn yeshiva to hide the origin of bribes paid in a multimillion-dollar mafia stock fraud scheme, according to fbi tapes.

james chickara, co-owner of the ranch 1 chain, has been captured on the undercover recordings saying he used the mesivta yeshiva rabbi chaim berlin on coney island ave. to launder bribes paid to brokers in the stock scams.

chickara and sebastian rametta, who the fbi says are associates of the colombo crime family, were co-owners of ranch 1 when they were arrested in june in a mammoth "mob on wall street" bust.

both men quietly pleaded guilty to stock fraud in manhattan federal court three weeks ago. rametta faces up to a year in jail, chickara up to 16 months.

the school is run by abraham fruchthandler, a politically connected real estate developer.

an assistant of fruchthandler, who has donated more than $22,000 to political candidates in the last four years, said he would not comment.

in their march 29 plea before judge william pauley, rametta and chickara admitted hiding an inflated commission paid to a broker to hype stock of their food retailer, manhattan soup man, which they modeled on "the soup nazi" character of the tv sitcom "seinfeld."

in talks secretly taped by the fbi, chickara said that he twice wrote checks to the brooklyn yeshiva and that school president fruchthandler tapped into yeshiva bank accounts to give cash back.

the yeshiva got a fee for its services, and chickara and rametta were able to claim a tax deduction for charitable giving, according to a talk secretly recorded dec. 14, 1999, between chickara and an informant named jeffrey pokross.

"we donated money to his yeshiva," chickara said. "let's say we gave him a $100,000 check. ... out of the yeshiva, he gave me back $75,000 or $80,000, actually $80,000 in cash."

pokross: "and you get the tax deduction?"

before their arrest, rametta was listed as ranch 1's ceo and chickara as its vice chairman. since then, they have been removed from the executive suite, though rametta continues working as a ranch 1 consultant and both still own stock in the firm.

the company owns 60 restaurants, including 23 in new york city, selling what it terms healthy fast food such as flame-broiled chicken sandwiches. current ceo george naddaff said the company had no knowledge of any wrongdoing by rametta and chickara.

rametta's lawyer, edward little, noted that in accepting his client's plea, prosecutors agreed to drop the mob-related racketeering charges.

little also questioned whether chickara actually laundered money through the yeshiva, though he couldn't say it didn't happen.

chickara's lawyer, robert gage, did not return calls seeking comment.

the guilty pleas tarnished the image of respectability the men have carefully maintained in cobbling together several multimillion-dollar business deals over the last decade.

the two sold arnie's bagelicious bagels to quaker oats in 1994, took the profits and started ranch 1 in 1996. they brought in several big-name investors, including john sculley, former ceo of apple computers.

at the same time, according to tapes made by the fbi, they were hanging around gangsters from the brooklyn neighborhood where they grew up.

actual:
monday, march 3th 2003, 1:20am

as a thin person who hasn't put any effort into being thin, i've never gotten much sympathy about gaining weight or feeling out of shape. that's all about to change. i got my body fat tested last month.

on the surface, nothing is different. i still appear thin and fit. but according to the national institutes of health, with a body-fat percentage of 32.4, i'm on the verge of being classified as overfat and slipping into high risk for serious health problems.

most people are aware that even when weight remains stable, an increase in body fat is associated with a higher risk of obesity, which can trigger heart disease, diabetes, high blood pressure and stroke. dieters have learned that muscle weighs more than fat, making the bathroom scale an imprecise gauge of physical fitness.

which is where body-fat gauges come in. the first system that attempted to measure body fat was the body mass index (bmi), a formula created by the centers for disease control based on height and weight. bmi is considered a good indicator of body-fat percentage - heavy people tend to have high body fat - but does not produce an exact number and often classifies very muscular people as obese.

coming to a gym near you

"a major league athlete was referred to us for weight loss because they thought his bmi was too high," says dr. steven heymsfield, deputy director of the new york obesity research centre at st. luke's-roosevelt hospital, "and it turned out he had virtually no fat at all."

to distinguish between fat and muscle, calipers and densitometry (underwater weighing) have been standard for more than a decade. more recently, dxa, an x-ray that measures bone density and fat, and bioimpedance analysis (bia) have been introduced.

no method is perfect. calipers, which determine fat percentages by pinching layers of skin, can be painful and are often administered by untrained gym staffers. caliper readings were found to be off by 50% in a recent good housekeeping institute test.

while currently considered the gold standard, underwater weighing (about $150) is time-consuming and uncomfortable. subjects must expel as much air as possible from their lungs and sit completely still while submerged in a tank of water, a process that may be repeated several times.

dxa (about $300) is simple and highly accurate but involves radiation, which most of us would prefer to avoid in a body-fat test. the bia method (about $35), based on the electrical conductivity of water-filled muscles versus fat, sends small electrical currents through the soles of the feet. though this is quick and easy, bloating can cause bia inaccuracies. because the current only goes as far as the hips, those with heavy middles may get incorrect results.

with the exception of the caliper and bmi, all methods are administered in a lab. combination fat analyzers and scales, manufactured by companies such as taylor and tanita, are good options for getting an approximate fat-percentage reading at home. the taylor 5553, found to be the most accurate by the good housekeeping institute, costs $49.99.

i was tested in a bod pod, a $35,000 egg-shaped chamber that measures body fat by means of air-displacement plethysmograph - in other words, how much air your body displaces. "a way to accurately, simply and safely test body fat has been unavailable to the medical community until now," says tom macleod, ceo of life measurement, inc., manufacturer of the bod pod. "our device is underwater weighing without the water."

the test, which costs about $125 (generally not covered by insurance), was administered at st. luke's-roosevelt hospital. after arriving at the body composition lab, i changed into a bathing suit, bathing cap and small booties, and removed all my jewelry. any extraneous material can contribute to errors.

after my height and weight were measured, i stepped inside the bod pod, which feels like a cross between a photo booth and sigourney weaver's spaceship bed in the "alien." the door was sealed and i sat still and breathed normally for about 60 seconds, occasionally hearing air rush into the pod. i was comfortable, but claustrophobics and people over 350 pounds or 7 feet should choose another method.

my results were printed by the attached computer within minutes. the report included my fat and lean body percentage, plus a breakdown of my fat and lean weight in pounds.

testing your body fat in a bod pod is simple and quick, but there aren't many available in the new york area. besides the machine at st. luke's-roosevelt, there are bod pods at brooklyn college and syracuse university. in other parts of the country, bod pods are being made available to the public via mobile service. the simpler bod pod st, which can produce a fast fat-percentage result but cannot store or manipulate data, is less expensive and should begin to appear in high-end gyms this year.

if you're interested in a bod pod appointment, or for more information, call 1-800-426-3763, or visit www.bodpod.com.

actual:
by david bianculli daily news tv critic

thursday, may 13th 2004, 7:20am

it's a jarring, but instructive, coincidence: the same week warner home video releases a dvd set with all the original season's episodes of "the jetsons," cartoon network revisits george and his space age family in a less-than-futuristic episode of "harvey birdman, attorney at law."

the "back to the present" episode of "harvey birdman," premiering sunday night at 11, is a riot. the 24-episode dvd set of "the jetsons," (four disks, $64.92), is a minor revelation.

after william hanna and joseph barbera struck prime-time gold in 1960 with "the flintstones," which translated "the honeymooners" into prehistoric animation, they tried again with "the jetsons."

the show imagined a future world - set in far-off 2002 - where meals were cooked by pushing a button, sidewalks moved while people stood still, tv was projected on giant screens, and people were whisked from one location to another via pneumatic glass tubes.

okay, so they were wrong about the tubes.

but unlike "the simpsons," an animated prime-time series that remains far and away the best-selling title on dvd, the old "jetsons" episodes don't reward repeated viewings. they punish them.

a more rewarding venture is "harvey birdman, attorney at law." three years ago, hanna-barbera optioned the rights to the characters in "birdman" - a very mature cartoon built around a character from a very immature hanna-barbera series.

a little history may help: in 1967, a few years after launching "jetsons" in prime time on abc (where it lasted one season), hanna-barbera presented a vapid saturday-morning series on nbc. it was called "birdman and the galaxy trio," and featured winged heroes trying to save the world.

birdman was a b-level hero even by hanna-barbera standards, so "harvey birdman, attorney at law" creators michael ouweleen and erik richter had no problem reimagining him as a suit-wearing, wing-sporting defense attorney, taking on cases brought to him by various characters in the hanna-barbera universe.

the best of these, from early in the run, reimagined fred flintstone as a mob boss, complete with an opening sequence that married those from "the flintstones" and "the sopranos." (its title: "dabba-dabba-don.")

for sunday's "harvey birdman," harvey is visited by the jetsons, who travel to harvey's time period to sue everyone for ruining the planet.

"we're from the future," george explains. "the magnificent, far-off year of 2002."

well, that is the 21st century, and george doesn't quite get - but audiences will - how the imagined future of "the jetsons" at times hasn't even kept pace with our own reality.

george provides harvey, for example, with a giant stack of evidence he claims will support his lawsuit.

"punch cards," he explains helpfully, taking a condescending tone. "in the future, that's how we input data into machines we call computers."

that's what i call funny.

and that's just what i don't call the original "jetsons." for now, save your money on the dvd set. maybe it'll be on sale, in the discount bins, in the very near future.

mix all ingredients in a bowl. at stone park, this dish is served with smoked bluefish cakes, but they also suggest pairing it with fried fish or barbecued ribs and chicken.

sunday, february 9th 2003, 1:95am

photographer annie leibovitz usually does the shooting, but wall street bond trader robert snider and his wife and infant son are aiming at her - with a $15 million lawsuit alleging vanity fair's top photographer ran a "terror campaign of harassment, provocation, destruction and terror" against them after he refused last summer to sell her their next-door landmark village townhouse on w. 11th st. the intensely personal complaint calls this "evil and reprehensible." howdy, neighbor!

the high - or low - point was reached, the suit alleges, when leibovitz's contractors dug beneath a shared load-bearing wall, knowing it would collapse. they also charge leibovitz with repeatedly cutting their phone lines, denying repairmen access, erecting sidewalk scaffolds without security measures, "the wholesale gutting" of her landmarked buildings, sledgehammering, drilling - you get the idea. all leading to "headaches, nausea, coughing, wheezing and insomnia," their house filling "with explosive fumes," and their forced removal by buildings department officials for safety reasons. then the roof opened, the pipes burst, there was a flood - and they lost almost everything. "this in order to extort the sale [of their house] at a bargain-basement price," the suit pounds home. all that's missing is a plague of locusts. there were rats, though. "we can't comment on a suit we don't know anything about," says leibovitz's business manager, rick kantor, who is also named in the suit.

john lennon would have turned 62 last october. his widow, yoko ono, turns 70 on feb. 18. to celebrate the milestone, their son, sean ono lennon, and his squeeze, actress and sometime party girl bijou phillips (herself a child of john phillips of the mamas and the papas), are taking over the midtown music-and-art-biz hangout mr. chow for the night and inviting 200 of yoko's nears and dears for cocktails and squab nibbles. with all due respect to the birthday girl, the word hopes someone other than yoko sings.

tuesday night, while the fashion flock sit like black crows on a wire in the front row of the fall designer shows, their latest nemeses will be celebrating the launch of a web site that regularly makes a meal of their bony carcasses.

yo, drudge! everyone who is anyone in chic manhattan is reading gawker.com - or should be. it's run by elizabeth spiers, a former equity analyst for venture capitalists and hedge funds, and nick denton, who covered technology for england's financial times before he caught the dot-com bug. gawker offers links to all the hottest gossip and shallowest chatter around (including the word), as well as daily digests of the best talk in town.

there's also the odd piece of original reporting, such as spiers' recent effort, asking wall street wonders how to find the perfect cocaine dealer. what's the point? "to say what other people can't," says spiers. "that's the fun of it."

geoffrey thomas, 59, has lived with lehman banking heiress sharon, countess sondes, the great-niece of 1930s new york gov. herbert lehman, for the last 17 years, while running jewelry-maker sasson-thomas. now he's hanging out with models one-third his age.

it's not what you think. after years of being told he was handsome enough to model, he let his pal ann dexter-jones, wife of foreigner's mick jones, set up a meeting for him at ford models, passed the audition, and now, this park ave. prince is pounding the pavement to go-sees and auditions.

"i'm the fresh face in town at almost 60," he boasts.

lady sondes won't let him quit his day job, though. "i don't want to give up all that free jewelry," she says.

at saks fifth avenue's dinner for fashion designer angela missoni, photographer patrick mcmullen tried to push the former and current editors of harper's bazaar together for a photo op. but glenda bailey skittered away from her predecessor, kate betts. "what can i say?" mcmullen sighed. "i mean well."

for sale: barneys? yes barneys

barneys new york, the deadly chic fashion chain that plunged into bankruptcy in 1996 after a wild expansion, is secretly for sale, according to several fashion types who have kicked its tires.

they say that grocery billionaire galen weston, the second-richest man in canada; peter rizzo, the former ceo of bergdorf goodman; marty staff, last seen atop hugo boss, and philip miller, the former head of marshall field and saks fifth avenue, all have expressed interest in yanking the chain.

though burdened by debt, barneys has been bettering its finances under current chairman howard socol, who came from the relatively down-market burdines chain. socol denies the store is for sale and david strumwasser, a managing director of whippoorwill associates, one of two vulture capital funds that own most of barneys, agrees: "you've got bad sources - the company is not actively for sale."

but vulture funds buy distressed companies and whip them into shape to sell them, and with fourth-quarter earnings about to be announced, barneys owners are said to see dry land from their so-far underwater investment.

"it's a very attractive property," says miller, now a merchant banker, who denies he's buying, but adds: "if they were selling, there would be buyers."

"they say they're not interested, but everyone knows it's for sale," says an actively interested party, who thinks the problem is that the company has lost two-thirds of its value - and should be marked down - while the owners want to get full retail. "they're looking for a bigger fool," another tire-kicker says.

a word to the wise

"it's only for the summer," you told all who asked when your husband moved out last year. but fall has turned to winter - and he's not only stayed away, he's shacked up with somebody else, and by all accounts, is happy as snoopy after nailing the red baron. and now, everyone's wondering if you'll keep your post position on manhattan's fast track without his power to propel you. this ain't small stuff, like losing your rolodex to a rival (even if it wasn't yours in the first place). it's a moment to consider the bridges you've burned, the price of your vendettas and how what goes around inevitably comes around. will your clients catch on that your juice is almost squeezed out? everyone in your world knows, so it's only a matter of time. speaking of which, you're no poulet de printemps. damage control - that's the ticket. sure you could console yourself with belgian chocolates, but why don't you wash your hair, give up smoking, try being nice for a change. look at it this way: who cares if it's good for your career - it might help you land a new man.

actual:
zawiya, libya — dozens of opposition fighters surrounded libya's last functioning oil refinery wednesday and laid siege to about 100 government troops, part of a push which brought them closer to seizing this strategic western city.

a rebel victory in zawiya could be a turning point in the six-month-old war and leave moammar gadhafi nearly cornered in his increasingly isolated stronghold of tripoli, the capital, just 50 kilometers (30 miles) to the east along the mediterranean coast.

rebel fighters are now closing in on the capital from the west and the south, while nato controls the seas to the north. the opposition is in control of most of the eastern half of the country and has declared benghazi, 1,000 kilometers (620 miles) east of tripoli, as its de facto capital.

wednesday's fighting focused around the sprawling refinery complex on the western outskirts of zawiya, a city of 200,000. the rebels, who began their assault on the refinery a day earlier, took control of the facility's three-story administration building, tearing down the gadhafi regime's green flag that flew over the grounds.

desperate gadhafi troops cut off from the main government forces took cover in a residential compound and closed the gates to prevent workers from fleeing, rebels said. the troops barricaded themselves in and positioned snipers on rooftops. an associated press photographer inside the refinery with rebel troops heard occasional bursts of gunfire.

an oil engineer in the compound told the ap that about 100 gadhafi soldiers remained inside late wednesday afternoon. at least several dozen rebel fighters were also in the area. arusi said his forces controlled parts of the complex.

the libyan rebels made a dramatic advance on saturday out of their bases in the western mountains near tunisia into zawiya on the mediterranean coast. since then, they have taken control of 70 percent of the city, rebel commanders say, and have been slowly gaining ground in fierce battles with gadhafi's forces.

the clashes at the refinery began on tuesday, then opposition fighters pulled out at nightfall and made a new push after daybreak, arusi said.

arusi said rebels wanted to take the refinery undamaged, and have been negotiating with gadhafi soldiers inside the refinery since entering zawiya on saturday. he said on tuesday morning, some of the regime fighters, all locals, surrendered to the rebels after several days of negotiations.

the remaining gadhafi loyalists closed the gate of the residential compound for refinery workers and their families. it was unclear how many people were living there. many of the workers were evacuated early in the civil war, which began in mid-february.

"if (the civilians) leave, we can deal with gadhafi's guys with full force," arusi said. "so gadhafi's guys don't want them to leave. they keep them as protection."

about half a mile south of the refinery, an ap reporter saw two cars carrying civilians driving away from the refinery on an otherwise deserted road. meanwhile, three pickup trucks loaded with fighters sped toward the refinery along the same road, to reinforce the troops.

a rebel field commander in zawiya, osama arusi, said the clashes at the refinery shut down an oil pipeline to tripoli, where a third of libya's 6 million people live.

"the pipeline from zawiya to tripoli has been switched off," arusi told the associated press. "the man who is responsible for switching the pipeline off said it is not working."

neither a pipeline shutdown nor a capture of the 120,000 barrel-per-day refinery in zawiya would have a major impact on gadhafi's ability to secure fuel, analysts said.

the flow of crude to the refinery from fields in the southwest of libya had largely halted since midsummer. the refinery was believed to be running at about one-third of its normal capacity, drawing mainly on crude oil that was in its storage tanks. at any rate, zawiya produces mostly fuel oil, not gasoline, which gadhafi had trucked in mainly from tunisia and to a lesser extent algeria.

"in that sense, it's more significant that they (the rebels) have got control of the roads than the refinery," said john hamilton, a libya energy expert with cross-border information and a contributing editor of africa energy. "strategically, that's a more important gain for the rebels. having control of the roads makes it much harder for gadhafi to get the petrol he needs" from tunisia and algeria.

in fighting elsewhere in the west, more than 45 wounded rebel fighters arrived in tunisia for medical care over the past 24 hours through the zintan border crossing, tunisia's official tap news agency reported.

outside the rebel-held city of misrata east of tripoli, opposition fighters said they captured the town of haysha, located halfway between misrata and gadhafi's hometown of sirte on the mediterranean coast. haysha was used by gadhafi forces as a base to fire rockets on misrata.

on the eastern front of the civil war, hundreds of miles from zawiya around the coastal town of brega, rebels clashed with gadhafi troops for control of the town's oil refinery. the front lines have swept through brega several times, and the oil facility there has not been operating for months.

a rebel doctor in brega, mohammed idris, said the field hospital in brega was overwhelmed by the number of casualties and that many wounded were sent to benghazi for treatment.

he said that at least 18 rebels had been killed and 74 wounded in fighting tuesday.

rebel fighter moussa ahmaid, who was escorting the wounded rebels to the hospital, said the fighting was mainly on the southern side of brega.

"we are using light hand-held weapons and mortars," he told the ap. "most of our casualties are from sniper fire or shrapnel from shelling."

ap business writer tarek el-tablawy in cairo contributed to this report.

sep 19th 2011, 15:02 by a.g. | london

it is exactly three years since economic woes began to dominate the minds of the british electorate, and such concerns show no sign of diminishing. according to the latest the economist/ipsos-mori poll, 59% of people identified the economy as one of the most important issues facing the country today.

meanwhile concerns about unemployment have crept up to second place, causing concern for 30% of the population. fears have been exacerbated by rising joblessness that has particularly affected the young.

the official unemployment rate for people aged under 25 in the three months to july was 20% (the poll was conducted before more recent, and equally concerning, figures were published on september 13th). the complete picture is a little less awful than portrayed because the unemployment rate is calculated as percentage of those who are either in work or looking for it, which excludes the many youngsters (almost half the population) who are in higher education. as a percentage of all those under 25, unemployment was about 13%—worrying but not terrifying.

still, the issue is at its most vexed since july 2009, six months after the start of the recent recession. unemployment lags behind economic trends, as struggling businesses shed staff or slow down any new recruitments. as the economy falters, the quest for jobs looks set to become a long one.

actual:
in the days following aol’s relaunch as a separate company, ceo tim armstrong is already looking to jettison some of its properties that take away from its new focus as a digital content producer. that means getting rid of properties and assets that don’t contribute to the aol brand and that don’t focus heavily on aol’s goals for the future.

as the wall street journal reports, aol is in talks to sell icq, the once prominent — but now archaic — instant messaging service. the wall street journal also says that bebo, the social network aol acquired in 2008 for a jaw-dropping $850 million, may be on the block. in the ensuing 20 months, bebo hasn’t quite turned out to be the profit center aol hoped it would be. although traffic was up after a redesign in february, bebo has continued to languish as european users migrate to facebook, like the rest of the world.

spending nearly $1 billion on bebo — which at this point is nearly a third of aol’s valuation as a separate entity — was just one of many, many missteps for the former web titan.

with icq, the situation is a bit less embarrassing. aol acquired icq in 1998 for $287 million. at the time, icq was a huge competitor to aol’s aim service, which had only recently become available to non-aol subscribers. the wall street journal says that icq’s potential buyer, facebook investor digital sky technologies, could pay as much as $300 million for the service. that’s not bad for a service that has never had a strong association with the aol brand.

it’s fascinating how quickly armstrong is making moves to streamline aol into a leaner, more focused company. what are you thoughts on the new aol? where does the bebo acquisition rank in the company’s long line of bad business moves?

the treasury department auctioned $35 billion in three-month bills at a discount rate of 0.035 percent, down from 0.130 percent last week; $30 billion in six-month bills was auctioned at a discount rate of 0.070 percent, down from 0.150 percent last week.

the three-month rate was the lowest since three-month bills averaged 0.010 percent on sept. 30. the six-month rate was the lowest since those bills averaged 0.060 percent on oct. 7.

for a $10,000 bill, the three-month price was $9,999.120 while a six-month bill sold for $9,996.46. that would equal an annualized rate of 0.035 percent for the three-month bills and 0.071 percent for the six-month bills.

actual:
san francisco — microsoft plans to offer a glimpse of its vision for windows this week, as its new chief executive seeks to redefine the company and recover from missteps with its flagship operating system.

although the new software won’t be formally released until next year, analysts already consider its success crucial for microsoft and satya nadella, who has made mobile devices and internet-based services priorities since becoming chief executive in february.

with its tablet-like touch controls, windows 8 had been microsoft’s answer to slumping sales in personal computers amid a rising demand for mobile devices. but the company alienated many users by forcing radical behavioral changes. research firm idc even blamed windows 8 for accelerating a decline in pc sales in the first full quarter following the system’s release in october 2012.

microsoft has released updates that address some of the complaints, yet analytics firm net applications estimates that five out of six windows users are still using something other than windows 8.

the next major release will be the company’s chance to regain its footing and show it can embrace mobile devices without sacrificing the traditional computing experience.

‘‘it’s one of the most important launches that they will ever have,’’ said patrick moorhead at the research firm moor insights and strategy. ‘‘it’s very important they get it right.’’

microsoft is expected to give an early look at some new features tuesday during an event the company has billed as a discussion about ‘‘what’s next for windows.’’ the company hasn’t said what it plans to call the new windows version.

the san francisco event is geared toward the business market. separate sessions focused on home computer users and others will be held in the coming months. analysts say the sessions are part of an effort by microsoft to gather feedback and avoid the stumbles it made with windows 8.

even after two years of declining sales of personal computers, software licenses for windows remain a key revenue stream for microsoft. such sales are a part of a business segment that contributes roughly 21 percent of microsoft’s annual revenue — second only to sales of the company’s commercial software.

windows 8 introduced a host of features for personal computers, including touch-screen functions that are now common with tablets. many pc users, however, found the redesigned interface difficult to navigate, particularly with keyboards and mice on devices without touch screens. they also missed familiar controls, such as the ‘‘start’’ button that was a longtime component of previous windows systems.

‘‘it was a miscalculation on the part of microsoft,’’ said analyst steve kleynhans at the gartner research firm. ‘‘you can’t force people into a situation where everything they know changes.’’

still, experts say, microsoft has good reason to design software that attempts to broaden its appeal to smartphone and tablet users. although the company still dominates the pc industry, that market is barely growing. meanwhile, microsoft has gained little traction in a booming smartphone market dominated by apple’s iphones and devices running google’s android software.

nadella has said he wants the next version of windows to be a ‘‘single, converged operating system for screens of all sizes.’’

actual:
many fans know ray lucas for his seven seasons in the nfl with the jets, dolphins and patriots. but in his new book, under pressure: how playing football almost cost me everything and why i'd do it all again, lucas and david seigerman give an uncensored look into the true culture of the nfl, and how the unending desire to stay on the field and in the league can lead to painkiller abuse and depression -- and end with fatal results. in this excerpt, lucas recounts how he plotted a suicide attempt.

one hundred million vehicles drive across the george washington bridge every year. i took it every time i drove home after practicing at the jets facility on long island. i'd take the cross island parkway to the throgs neck bridge to the cross bronx expressway to the gw, the busiest bridge in the world.

i was well acquainted with the george washington bridge, but i still felt i probably needed to drive it one more time. i needed to see it with a new set of eyes, not as a commuter looking to get home to his family, but as a man on a very different mission. i needed to find the best place along its mile-long span to drive my truck off the road and into the hudson river 200 feet below.

that was the basic plan. i just needed to iron out the specifics.

i got in my truck and drove to the bridge, as clear and coherent as i had been in months. i was living in the moment, my endorphins flowing. this was going to work out all right after all.

i crossed over into manhattan, scanning the possibilities provided by the upper level. all of a sudden, i was at the line of scrimmage, looking over the defense for a weakness one last time. i took note of the little guardrail that separated the pedestrian walkway from the four lanes of eastbound traffic.

this could make things a little tough.

so, i looped around and drove back the other way, heading west to fort lee. there's no westbound toll on the george washington bridge. things were looking up already.

the westbound side didn't appear to have any more favorable options. it looked challenging, but not impossible.

good idea. i needed to check the lower level. once i got back into jersey, i turned around and did another loop of the bridge. i was really getting into this fact-finding expedition. i was laughing to myself and smiling. i even started to break into a little sweat.

but the lower level was no good -- steel support beams in an unbroken pattern of upright triangles all the way across. i couldn't have blasted my truck through those. i checked the lower level on the way back, too, just to be sure. same deal.

guess it's going to have to be the upper level.

guess so. but i needed to do one more lap, just to make sure. i wound up making three consecutive round trips across the george washington bridge in a red truck that day, and no one noticed. you would've thought someone would have found this slightly suspicious and pulled my ass over. no one gets so lost that they do three laps around the gw.

but no one stopped me. must have been my lucky day.

after exiting the upper level for the third and final time, i headed home to harrison.

i'd planned my work. soon, it'd be time to work my plan.

i would go on sunday morning, after cecy and our three girls left for church. i would drive to the gw, take the upper level approach, get through the tolls and the merge from 12 lanes down to four, pick a lane, and floor it. i knew i would need to pick up a high rate of speed, so that when i made my hard right, probably just beyond the halfway point, i'd have enough momentum to clear the guardrail, the pedestrian lane, and, finally, the outer guardrail. i figured my truck had the weight to carry me up and over, if i was going fast enough. as long as i didn't get caught up by one of the 592 steel suspender ropes that hold the bridge in place, i'd break through.

i figured somebody would see me go over. they'd see a red truck with jersey tags, maybe even catch a few numbers off my license plate. someone would be able to figure out who it was and get the news to my family.

i like it. let's go.

true to the southern california culture, the halos presented jeter with a pinstripe paddleboard.

keeping with the local culture theme, the astros gave the captain a pair of personalized cowboy boots, a cowboy hat and some golf clubs.

the indians, who play in the city that is considered by some the birthplace of rock n' roll, gave jeter a personalized guitar.

the mariners presented jeter with a chair from the old kingdome, a base from safeco field and a $5,000 check for his turn 2 foundation. not pictured here is the $34,000 jay-z hublot that jeter's former teammate, robinson cano, gave him.

during a rare trip to yankee stadium, the reds gave jeter framed autographed jerseys of davey concepcion and barry larkin. the frame also included photos from june 3, 2003, the day jeter was named the 14th yankees captain before a game against the reds in cincinnati.

on behalf of the white sox, paul konerko presented jeter with a miniature bench made of out bats, balls and bases, u.s. cellular field shortstop dirt in a glass container adorned with legendary shortstops' names and a $5,000 check for the turn 2 foundation.

jeter got another pair of cowboy boots from texas' other team along with a framed photo of jeter and then-president george w. bush from game 3 of the 2001 world series at yankee stadium. the former owner of the rangers was on hand to present the gift to jeter.

the twins gave jeter the last second base from the metrodome. that bag was used during game 3 of the 2009 alds, when jeter and the yankees beat the twins, 4-1.

jeter received the no. 2 from wrigley field's famed hand-operated scoreboard.

the crosstown mets presented jeter with a no. 2 subway mosaic as well as a $22,222 check for the turn 2 foundation.

detroit's tribute was extra emotional for jeter, who grew up in kalamazoo, mich. with jeter's family on the field, the tigers presented him with a $5,000 check for the turn 2 foundation, a pair of seats from tiger stadium and a trio of paintings of jeter dating back to his high school days.

in addition to a $10,000 check to his foundation, the a's presented jeter with a personalized bottle of napa valley wine.

the brewers presented jeter with a bronze replica of his bat, a stay at the prestigious american club and a round of golf at whistling straits in kohler, wis.

actual:
cereal maker post holdings inc said it would acquire privately held rival mom brands co for about $1.15 billion in cash and stock to expand in the bagged and hot cereal categories.

post, the maker of raisin bran and honey bunches of oats, will pay $1.05 billion in cash and issue 2.5 million shares to the owners of mom brands.

mom brands’ ready-to-eat food and cereal brands include malt-o-meal, frosted mini spooners, golden puffs, cinnamon toasters, fruity dyno-bites, better oats, and three sisters.

post has been aggressively pursuing deals since it was spun off from ralcorp holdings in 2012. the cereal maker said in april that it would buy egg and dairy producer and distributor michael foods inc for $2.45 billion.

post said on monday that richard koulouris, former president of ralcorp’s food group, would lead the combined cereal business of mom brands and post. he will join post on feb. 9.

conagra foods inc acquired ralcorp in january 2013.

post also estimated net sales of about $1.07 billion and adjusted earnings before interest, taxes, depreciation, and amortization of about $126 million-$128 million for the first quarter ended dec. 31.

analysts on average were expecting net sales of $1.07 billion, according to thomson reuters i/b/e/s.

barclays and credit suisse are post’s financial advisers for the deal and lewis, rice & fingersh lc is its legal adviser.

bofa merrill lynch is mom brands’ financial adviser and faegre baker daniels llp is its legal adviser.

post’s shares closed at $41.44 on the new york stock exchange on friday.

prediction: 4— attorney general william french smith said today that a new federal task force created to investigate serious abuses in the food stamp program would focus initially on charges of massive fraud in new york city. officials in new york city's food stamp program have denied the charges. creation of the unit was disclosed yesterday by justice department officials.
actual:
washington, sept. 4— attorney general william french smith said today that a new federal task force created to investigate serious abuses in the food stamp program would focus initially on charges of massive fraud in new york city.

mr. smith, in formally announcing creation of the unit, said that the justice department already had directed the united states attorneys for the southern and eastern districts of new york to intensify their efforts to identify and wipe out fraud in the federally financed program.

justice department officials said the unit was being formed partly as a reaction to reports that officials in new york city were unwilling to pursue fraud cases and had blocked the efforts of their own investigators.

several former and current investigators complained about lack of support from city officials in a meeting in washington on sunday with an associate attorney general, rudolph w. giuliani. officials in new york city's food stamp program have denied the charges.

the attorney general said that both united states attorneys' offices would receive additional investigative assistance from the federal bureau of investigation, the department of agriculture and the united states postal service.

creation of the unit was disclosed yesterday by justice department officials. d. lowell jensen, the assistant attorney general in charge of the criminal division, will oversee the nationwide effort. the fraud i nvestigation became anissue today in the new york city mayoral elect ion when a candidate in the democratic primary, state assemblyman f rank j. barbaro, used the food stamp reports to accuse mayor koch of covering up wrongdoing in the city's human resources administratio n. waste called 'staggering'

at a city hall news conference, mr. koch denied the charges and asserted that the city had taken steps last year to reduce the number of fraudulent food stamp claims each month from 12,500 to fewer than 100. the mayor also denied charges that city officials had harassed employees who sought to bring the controversy into the open.

the attorney general described as ''staggering'' the amount of fraud and waste in food stamp programs in new york and in other cities.

he said that government agencies have had ''many successes'' in combating fraud, and noted that 450 indictments had been brought this year. he added, however, that ''with the addtional resources i have now redeployed from the criminal division and the f.b.i., we can and will do more.''

one of the more important agencies that will be involved in the task force effort is the agriculture department. the 450 indictments noted by mr. smith were bought as a result of investigations by the department's inspector general.

the reagan administration has cut the number of employees in the inspector general's office to 880 from 930.

''not in there, bet,'' said prince philip. that was the queen, my lord,'' a waiter said. '' one hot summer evening in the 60's, brendan behan, the distinguished irish playwright, descended from a taxi in front of an old and distinguished london club. naturally he had taken several rounds of what the indians called ''make brave'' to sustain him on the trip. the watchers were totally unequipped to deal with this. i've come about the bloody television,'' said behan. the professor asked behan one question and got a string of slurred obscenities in reply.
actual:
men's clubs appear to be increasingly in the center of controversy these days -the question of female membership in particular has raised some hackles. but i still regard them fondly. as a member at various times of six clubs in paris, london and new york and as a visitor to others in singapore, dublin, milwaukee, cairo, san francisco, boston and kuala lumpur, i have always found them to be places of comfort, where for a few hours one can escape the abrasions of business and the demands of family.

in fact, every club i know looks askance at the member or visitor who produces business papers. recently i heard a financial bigwig being told off by a club porter for attempting to introduce a portfolio into a club. not long ago a peer of the realm was upbraided by the committee of an old london club for handing another member a brochure depicting the joys of a vacation on the tunisian coast, to which he intended to repair.

an innocent author may be seduced by a couple of martinis fed him by an unusually generous publisher to accept a down payment on a book much below his original figure. (no records exist of a publisher raising the down payment after being bought a couple of drinks by an author, probably because very few authors are willing or able to risk the cost of two drinks on what manifestly is a very long shot.) but business is something most men go to clubs to escape.

conversations at a club may wander from the disturbing situation in poland to the jets' need to get back into the national football league race, but in most two subjects are barred: women and professional matters. the late peter fleming, an amateur of social history, held that this rule was an extension of the duke of wellington's ukase against discussion of these subjects in an officers' mess on the ground that they were the most likely to lead to violent argument and ultimately a duel.

club conversation, i have found, is often witty, informed and spiced with humor. within the confines of a club a senator, a cabinet minister or a cleric can relieve himself of that ''perilous stuff that weighs upon the soul.'' the speaker can be absolutely sure that what he says will not go beyond its walls. of course, the club member must take the rough with the smooth. every club i know has its bores, and often a chief bore, and the new member or visitor is warned against them.

the worst in my experience was a member of a london club known for the levity of its conversation. he once cornered dan macmillan, the former prime minister harold's elder brother, and began a long recital of his adventures in some tin-pot campaign in world war i.

when mr. macmillan showed signs of restiveness, the bore said aggrievedly, ''i don't think you want me to finish this story.'' ''that's exactly what i do want,'' said mr. macmillan. clubs vary as much as their members. one in london was once described as a quiet subbranch of the british museum. on a still day the snores emitted by high members of the clergy resting after lunch can be heard as far as piccadilly circus. it was the scene of one of the best club stories.

an eminent peer and former cabinet minister walked daily from his home in westminster to another, livelier club. en route it was his custom to use ''the facilities,'' as the british call them, in the quieter establishment. some members took umbrage. they objected to the sight of a nonmember, no matter how exalted, using their club in this manner. they instructed the hall porter, the figure around whom the workings of all clubs revolve, to inform the peer that it was a club he was using when next he stopped.

the porter did so. ''oh, it's a club, too, is it,'' said the peer, and departed. some clubs are learned. once, during world war ii, i listened in dublin's kildare street club to a most instructive dissertation on joyce's ''ulysses,'' given, with the aid of a couple of brandies, by a slightly motheaten professor. in the salisbury club in what was then rhodesia and is now zimbabwe, i heard two planters sketching the path of arab slave traders across their adjoining plantations. they cited a wealth of archeological and social data. they were not showing off; they were interested and hoped others would be.

club food, it must be admitted, is rarely distinguished. the wouldbe reformers who conjure up pictures of men wading through meals that would put brillat-savarin to shame are well off the mark.

a gifted cockney chef in a london club said he had discovered early in his career that it was no use tempting the members with high-toned productions or dainty tidbits.

''wot they wants,'' he said, ''is something wot sticks to their ribs; beef, lamb, grouse, salmon. good cheese. sometimes a strengthenin' drop of soup. but nothing fancy-like.''

whether the food is good or bad, the wine is likely to be excellent. in some london clubs it is customary for elderly bachelors to will their wine cellars to their clubs. the wine is sold at the price the deceased paid. in one club the members passed a memorable autumn drinking a chateau talbot of a superlative year at about $1.50 a magnum.

all clubs have territorial limits. the lounge of one in london is forbidden to all visitors. once in the 60's the queen arrived for a private dinner party and darted into the lounge to look at the pictures, which are memorable.

''not in there, bet,'' said prince philip. the queen left. an elderly member napping by the fire awoke and asked, ''who was that woman - what was she doing here?'' ''that was the queen, my lord,'' a waiter said. ''well, dammit, she shouldn't be here, members only you know.'' one hot summer evening in the 60's, brendan behan, the distinguished irish playwright, descended from a taxi in front of an old and distinguished london club. he had flown from dublin to london, which to him was a frightening experience. naturally he had taken several rounds of what the indians called ''make brave'' to sustain him on the trip. he had come to london to appear on a very cerebral bbc program devoted to the arts and was to meet his interlocutor, a member, at the club. as it happened, about a dozen of the club's elderly members had gathered around the television to watch the last match of the cricket series between england and australia, an event of transcendent interest, to be compared with the super bowl or the last game of the world series.

suddenly the television set went blank. the watchers were totally unequipped to deal with this. they telephoned at once for a repairman and the most senior of the group was deputized to go to the front door to escort the repairman to the set.

the taxi, at that moment, decanted behan, sweating profusely with his coat over his back. ''who are you?'' asked the clubman. ''i've come about the bloody television,'' said behan. he was immediately led to the set, where his ignorance of the machine was soon manifest. then it was learned that he had come to the club as a guest.

the cricket addicts had infringed one of clubland's basic laws; they had been rude to a guest of a member in the club. they had no recourse. behan was escorted to the bar where he was plied with strong drink, which he needed about as much as a second head. by the time he arrived at the bbc for his program he was in a sorry state.

the producer, also a member, reported the next day that it had been the shortest interview on record. the professor asked behan one question and got a string of slurred obscenities in reply. the bbc's reaction was rapid. as i recall it, the program was switched to an elevating film about roman ruins in britain.

prediction: some say that the national voting rights act discriminates against the south. at present, before redistricting, there are 43 council seats, 8 held by blacks and hispanics. the council has taken a reckless gamble with orderly city government. even if the plan should survive washington's scrutiny, the council owes the city a thorough overhaul of its districting structure, including proposals to amend the city charter if necessary. meanwhile, does the voting rights law need to be renewed?
actual:
some say that the national voting rights act discriminates against the south. new york city is learning that it is binding in all respects in manhattan, brooklyn and the bronx. the city council has made such a mess of its 1981 redistricting that its plan probably violates the federal law. so the sept. 10 primary will be held under a legal cloud; even the november general election could be invalidated.

the numbers make their own eloquent point. at present, before redistricting, there are 43 council seats, 8 held by blacks and hispanics. but since 1970, the black and hispanic proportion of the population has risen from 24 percent to nearly 40 percent. so what does the council offer? a plan giving minorities 8 of 45 seats.

no wonder that this plan runs afoul of a guiding principle at the justice department, which must approve any new plan: minorities should be no worse off than before. the reagan administration applied that rule just last month in striking down a virginia legislative reapportionment.

the council, far from demonstrating that it is nondiscriminatory, has instead raised new questions. hence the justice department has called for detailed additional information.

the council's main justification is that minorities are too scattered among the boroughs to permit creating new minority districts. the justice reaction seems - not to put too fine a point on it - skeptical. citizen groups have charged that the council was much more interested in preserving the seats of incumbents, of whatever race, than in giving minorities a fair share of electoral power.

redistricting is complicated business, but the council was not confused. for instance, it drew the 25th district in brooklyn in such a way that the white incumbent, theodore silverman, who is chairman of the council's election committee, has a much better chance of keeping his seat. blacks were siphoned off to other districts and whites added so that his 84 percent black constituency became less than 60 percent.

the log-rolling goes in both directions. black and hispanic incumbents, having the same instinct for self-preservation as their white colleagues, went along with the council plan. it is doubly disappointing when not even they are dependable protectors of the political rights of minority voters. the voting rights act requires proof that the self-preservation is not bought at minorities' expense.

the council has taken a reckless gamble with orderly city government. even if the plan should survive washington's scrutiny, the council owes the city a thorough overhaul of its districting structure, including proposals to amend the city charter if necessary. meanwhile, does the voting rights law need to be renewed? new york may end up as exhibit a.

prediction: fact and logic were never allowed to intrude on her opinions. the wife of one of the wealthiest men in britain, she enjoyed luxury but fought tirelessly for the poor. she had no capacity for organizing her thoughts, and her critical faculties, though in some ways very acute, were in other ways surprisingly limited.'' it is to his credit that this in no way detracts from the substance of his book or the research that went into it. the motivation and background of the ''cliveden set,'' the british establishment figures who gathered at the astor home in the 1930's, and who were accused of fostering the appeasement of nazi germany, are explained perhaps as well as they ever will be. there is an era portrayed here, as well as an individual. he notes, too, that his hostess presided ''like a blend between juno at the siege of troy, and one of the leading valkyries caracoling over an appropriate battlefield.'' illustrations: photo of sargent's painting of lady astor
actual:
by enid nemy nancy astor. a biography. by anthony masters. illustrated. 237 pages. mcgraw-hill. $10.95. nancy astor. a lady unashamed. by john grigg. illustrated. 192 pages. lit- tle, brown. $15.

fact and logic were never allowed to intrude on her opinions. she was a stubborn woman and a bigoted one, fiercely independent, often less than pleasant, and capable of outright cruelty. she was also one of the most fascinating and powerful women of her time. the power diminished long before her death, the fascination lingers on. the first woman elected to the british house of commons, nancy astor is now a historical statistic, but she is a compelling one.

the complexities of her character are explored in detail in these two books, and for anyone interested but not committed to the subject, it's a toss-up as to which paints the better picture. both are objective and straightforward, and neither makes any attempt to burnish legend or gloss over imperfections. the lady who confronts us is very real, with as many warts as beauty spots. mass of contradictions

one of three beautiful langhorne sisters of virginia, nancy astor was a mass of contradictions and inconsistencies. a woman who disliked sex, she married twice and bore six children, to whom she was a dutiful, if not exemplary mother. the wife of one of the wealthiest men in britain, she enjoyed luxury but fought tirelessly for the poor. a passionate believer in temperance, she served the best brandies and wine to her guests, sometimes to their surprise. the late duke of windsor, while still prince of wales, was apparently prepared to bring his own spirits to cliveden, the astor estate, but refrained when his equerry was told that it would not be necessary to go to such lengths.

her friends were the great of the time - lord lothian, t.e. lawrence, lloyd george - and she hoarded them as a miser does gold, but tolerated no straying from her all-enveloping fold. she was, if not overtly anti-semitic, certainly inclined in that direction, a tendency aggravated by her friendship with the writer hilaire belloc. yet she is quoted as saying that eventually she had to give up belloc because he had two manias - against the jews and against the rich. which mania was uppermost in her decision is a moot point.

she disdained reason (one friend said ''reason was not a weapon she cared to use much, if at all'') for intuition and emotion. ''she was a very intelligent woman, but her intelligence was always more intuitive than cerebral,'' says mr. grigg. ''she had no capacity for organizing her thoughts, and her critical faculties, though in some ways very acute, were in other ways surprisingly limited.''

the author of a british broadcasting corporation television documentary on nancy astor, mr. grigg is perhaps the lighter and livelier writer of the two. it is to his credit that this in no way detracts from the substance of his book or the research that went into it. his access to letters written by lady astor to her sister phyllis, and the co-operation he received from the astor family, were obviously of immeasurable help, and although the result is both intimate and revealing, it is not prurient.

his own asides and comments are equally judicious, and often delightful. ''i am sure god meant us to use humility with discretion,'' he quotes lady astor as saying, and then comments, ''in that sense, if in no other, her discretion was impeccable.''

discussing nancy astor's friendship with george bernard shaw, he notes that ''gbs agreed to have his beard trimmed and washed by nancy's hairdresser, but did not cut his political opinions to suit hers.''

mr. masters's somewhat more scholarly book gives equal time to lady astor's childhood, marriages, feminism, political career and christian science beliefs, but it is particularly engrossing when it deals with the latter part of her life.

the motivation and background of the ''cliveden set,'' the british establishment figures who gathered at the astor home in the 1930's, and who were accused of fostering the appeasement of nazi germany, are explained perhaps as well as they ever will be.

''in fact, they were naive and over-optimistic,'' he says. ''for intellectual and non-violent people they were conspicuous in their ability to blind themselves to hitler's violence.'' an era portrayed

he paints, too, a vivid and poignant portrait of lady astor's declining years, her unwilling retirement from parliament in 1944, her partial estrangement from her husband and her subsequent rather aimless life.

there is an era portrayed here, as well as an individual. one charming vignette is of tea at cliveden, described by walter elliott, a favored guest and conservative parliamentary colleague, as having the ambiance of a bedouin encampment. he notes, too, that his hostess presided ''like a blend between juno at the siege of troy, and one of the leading valkyries caracoling over an appropriate battlefield.''

it's very likely that nancy astor would have enjoyed the description.

actual:
wilton to june havoc, dancing was once a survival mechanism, a means to a meal. today, it is sharing and having fun. the actress, author and director, who endured dance marathon contests for thousands of hours in dingy halls during the depression, is staging a ''dance in the streets'' this afternoon in cannon crossing, her enclave of restored shops in the cannondale section of wilton, about two miles north of wilton center on route 7. she said she has invited ''everyone in the state'' and will be sending in the clowns ''to mix with the people.'' the event is scheduled to last from noon until 5 p.m., but under miss havoc's direction, it may last longer.

with cannon crossing miss havoc has parlayed her passion for preservation into a thriving business enterprise. unable to bear what she said was the ''sad disintegration'' of the area, she purchased eight acres of run-down buildings four years ago, converted them into a center of quaint antique and crafts shops, and rented them.

last year, the conversion was capped when miss havoc bought an old one-room school house (circa 1872) on route 7. with her flair for theatricality - and with a little help from 88 friends, accompanied by the wilton high school marching band - she had it moved over to cannon crossing, where it is now a restaurant.

she has a flair for self-promotion as well. in most of the shops, autographed copies of the second in miss havoc's series of autobiographical memoirs, ''more havoc,'' published by harper & row last year, are strategically displayed, inscribed ''with love.''

''early havoc,'' the first book, was about her beginnings in vaudeville at the age of two, and the squalid marathon days. her relationship with her predatory stage mother, rose, and her sister louise, who became gypsy rose lee, are explained in ''more havoc.'' a third book, ''ever havoc,'' is scheduled to be published.

miss havoc lives on six acres behind the shops, where she tends to her eight dogs, two burros, two goats, 22 chickens, 50 birds and the swans and geese she hasn't counted. ''they delight my heart,'' she said. ''they're my entertainment. some people go to nightclubs. i go to my menagerie.''

miss havoc continues to appear in movies and plays. but her most recent forays into film, ''can't stop the music,'') and theater, ''jitters,'' were flops. many referred to the film, released last year, as ''can't stand the music'' and the play, which was bound for broadway last month, closed en route, in philadelphia.

''that was a mystifying experience. it never happened to me before.'' she said. ''the play was very successful in little theaters'' - it played at the long wharf theater's stage 2 - ''but they didn't want to change anything to make it suitable for a broadway-size house,'' she maintained.

miss havoc bought her first house in weston 25 years ago, but it wasn't until 15 years later that she decided connecticut was home. ''i had a brownstone in the city and some depraved citizens came in an vandalized that beautiful 100-year-old building with all the rococo plaster and original brass rings and i felt violated,'' she said.

of her life in connecticut, she said: ''i never had neighbors before. i never knew who anybody was and i don't think i tried. i never was involved with anyone local and here i am. this is more than doing benefits. this is going to town meetings because you care where the ground fill is put and what happens to that river and you get up and fight for it.''

''cannon crossing has turned into something more satisfying than having anyone say 'i loved your book' or 'i saw your performance,' '' she said. ''this is my life.''

actual:
inwood local residents have long regarded this unincorporated community next to affluent lawrence in the five towns as the stepchild of the town of hempstead and the nassau county government. but now town officials have advised them that a long-range revitalization plan is in the works that will improve both the community's status and its economy.

the plan includes new housing, the renovation of commercial areas, the upgrading of recreational facilities and improvements in streets, sidewalks and lighting. according to eugene k. ferencik, deputy commissioner of the town's department of planning and economic development, $500,000 in community development funds will be spent for the first phase of a three-year project, and he is optimistic that there will be future funds for the project.

the revitalization plan is aimed at improving sections of inwood that are dilapidated and overrun with rubble, weeds and gutted buildings. the main target areas are expected to be doughty boulevard and bayview avenue, and lawrence avenue at the lawrence village line. groundbreaking is scheduled to begin next spring for 150 new housing units for the elderly and the handicapped. these will be called mary's manor.

mary's manor will rise on both east and west sides of doughty boulevard and will be managed by the halandia management corporation of oceanside. the human development office of the rockville centre roman catholic diocese and the town of hempstead jointly obtained more than $7 million in construction funds from the united states department of housing and urban development.

''we have built one development in selden'' - st. joseph's village - ''and this will be our second,'' said john gregory, the executive secretary of the human development office of the diocese.

thirteen one-family homes will be built on scatttered sites that have already been cleared. according to sandra victor, the director of urban renewal for the town of hempstead, a public hearing will be held tuesday on the model for the homes that are to be built by the halandia corporation.

as part of the housing-improvement plan, low-interest loans will be made available to homeowners who are interested in renovating properties in need of major repair. some people who cannot afford to borrow will receive outright grants.

the inwood revitalization project also calls for new businesses to come into the area to provide employment. one concern - an importexport company - has filed an application to build at sheridan boulevard; two other companies are expected to come into the area as well.

a spokesman for united states senator alfonse m. d'amato, republican, who started the project while he was hempstead town presiding supervisor, said, ''we are hoping to create a good climate for private business by upgrading the entire area.''

community leaders expressed optimism as well as some skepticism about the revitalization plan. sadie e. scott, the executive director of the five towns community center, said, ''the $500,000 is just a drop in the bucket because we've got a long way to go in order to improve our way of life here.''

''for years we had nothing but promises, promises, like the song in the broadway show,'' said jesse mistero, inwood's fire commissioner and a lifelong resident of the area. ''we had a history of being neglected by every level of government. however, i believe that at long last we're going to get action.''

''it's time our officials gave us cause to erase our self-image of neglect,'' said the rev. judith m. bennett, pastor of st. paul's united methodist church. ''i wonder if the funds for all the planned improvements will really be made available.''

mr. ferencik of the town planning department said that ''although the reagan administration has proposed cuts in h.u.d. funding, the federal funds to be used for this first phase of community development and housing were approved and allocated while the carter administration was still in office.''

two state legislators also expressed opinions on the subject. assemblyman arthur j. kremer, the long beach democrat who is chairman of the assembly's ways and means committee, said: ''it's not time to break out the champagne yet. i would urge the residents to take this news with guarded optimism.''

state senator carol berman, democrat of lawrence, said, ''it's about time that the town finally came through for this long-neglected area.''

local civic leaders say the major reason for inwood's decline as a community was a project known as the nassau expressway, which was planned by the state department of transportation more than 30 years ago but never built.

in an action that some local residents refer to as ''rockefeller's follies,'' the state condemned a large section of inwood for the expressway, forcing people to leave their homes, then abandoned the area. the area is now occupied largely by rats and weeds, a situation that owners of adjoining properties in the doughty boulevard area say has caused their parcels to decline in value.

the state department of transportation recently announced that it would seek federal funds to finally get the ''phantom roadway'' started.

actual:
new york— sears. rca. gulf and western. national steel. baldwin united. greyhound. general electric. control data. not to mention american express, merrill lynch, prudential, beneficial and transamerica.

these are the bankers of today. and the list goes on. need a loan? want to make a deposit? get a line of credit? sign up for a credit card, an auto loan, a second mortgage, a first mortgage? americans no longer need banks to satisfy their financial needs. nor are the banks themselves ''just banks'' any more. they are, or are trying to be, go-go financial marketers. they prefer to call themselves ''financial services companies,'' just like the american expresses and the merrill lynches.

the banks are even finding ways around federal laws that prohibit them from engaging in certain activities or branching across state lines. despite the glass-steagall act of 1933, which bars commercial banks from many investment banking activities, the bankamerica corp. recently announced that it planned to buy charles schwab & co., one of the nation's largest discount brokerage firms.

the very definition of what banking or financial services entail expands almost daily. many financiers would include real estate brokerage, executive relocation and sophisticated communications networks as part of their ''financial services'' package.

banks are busy sending up communications satellites and building earth stations to receive signals from outer space. and a number of the nonfinancial companies that are expanding their financial businesses, such as the international telephone and telegraph corp., happen also to be in communications.

the reason: financial services is, most basically, the movement of money, and the movement depends on high-technology communications. thus, american express spent about $250 million this year to operate and expand its computer operations. and it is spending another $35 million to build an earth station in salt lake city that will enable it to approve transactions within seconds anywhere in the world.

such expenses, plus the growing competition from new entries into the field, have been prompting mergers of once fiercely independent concerns. the bache group has been swallowed by the prudential insurance co. shearson loeb rhoades is part of american express. dean witter reynolds is becoming part of sears. salomon brothers was merged into the phibro corp., a large commodities-trading company, and dillon read was acquired by the bechtel family, owner of the world-renowned engineering firm.

does it make sense and where will it end? to companies already in some aspects of the financial business, it seems that the only way to compete is to offer a full range of services - to become a financial department store. to those who are not yet in it, providing financial services appears to have a lot of obvious pluses:

- to industrial companies that have been trying to keep up with costly pollution regulations, finance seems exquisitely clean. - to companies in heavy industry that need to spend billions of dollars to ''reindustrialize'' out-of-date plants, entry into the financial business seems cheap.

- to corporations that have been hurt by high labor costs, financial services seems not to be labor-intensive. - to industries that have been badly hurt by competition from foreign imports, finance seems impervious to inroads from abroad. but the rush may well be risky, as those with more experience in the field have found. like many other industries, the financial services business tends to be cyclical. securities firms are very attractive investments now because most have performed well for the past few years. that certainly has not always been the case, however, and may not always be. the financial services field is becoming both more capital- and labor-intensive, some analysts say. as noted, to efficiently serve a mass market, huge sums must be invested in technology. and it takes highly paid executives - a lot of them - to deal with the more sophisticateded individualized needs of upscale customers.

finally, what seems to be highly profitable often isn't. take the money-market funds, which have attracted more than $175 billion in the last few years. merrill lynch, whose money-market fund accounts for about one-fifth of the market, doesn't claim that the fund itself is making any money. merrill hopes that the fund will generate other, more profitable, business.

that was the dream commercial banks lived with for years, until competition forced them to figure out whether they really were earning money on many of their services. the answer, for the most part, turned out to be no, and that is why many banks today are raising the price of their consumer services.

each financial service, as many banks have learned to the tune of heavy losses, is a very different business. because a company knows how to make mortgages does not mean it knows how to make a personal loan or underwrite insurance.

but the trend toward financial conglomeration is real and is likely to continue for the foreseeable future, as witnessed by the following vignettes of a number of nonbank companies that have become significant factors in the financial-services business.
